Bootstrap is a popular open-source CSS framework that provides a set of pre-built components, styles, and tools for building responsive web interfaces. It offers a wide range of UI elements and utilities for creating consistent and visually appealing websites and applications.

Use Bootstrap when you want a well-established and widely supported CSS framework with a large community and extensive documentation. It's suitable for projects where you need a responsive and consistent design system with a variety of customizable components.

Avoid Bootstrap if you prefer a more lightweight or utility-first CSS approach, or if you need a design that significantly deviates from the default Bootstrap styles. Also, consider the potential for CSS bloat and the need to override default styles for extensive customization.
Bootstrap is framework agnostic and works everywhere
Bootstrap has 32 Components, 28 of them are unique â€“ for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
Bootstrap has light and dark themes
Does not support more than 2 themes at the same time
Bootstrap CSS file is available on CDN
Bootstrap uses semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
Bootstrap provides component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
Bootstrap does not require a Node.js environment
Bootstrap does not provide micro CSS files for each component
Bootstrap does not use wide-gamut P3 colors by default
Bootstrap uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
Bootstrap doesn not use native CSS nesting

daisyUI is a component library for Tailwind CSS that provides pre-designed components with theming capabilities. It is framework-agnostic, meaning it can be used in any web project, and it doesn't ship any JavaScript to the browser.

Use daisyUI when you want to rapidly prototype or build a project with a consistent design system based on Tailwind CSS. It's well-suited for projects where you need a large variety of customizable components and theme options without writing a lot of custom CSS.

Avoid daisyUI if you need highly specific or unique component designs that deviate significantly from the pre-designed styles. Also, if you prefer to build all components from scratch for maximum control over every detail, daisyUI might not be the best choice.
daisyUI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
daisyUI has 61 components, 57 of them are unique â€“ for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
daisyUI supports unlimited themes at the same time, allowing for dynamic theme switching.
daisyUI doesn't ship JavaScript to browsers
daisyUI has no dependencies. It's immune to 3rd party vulnerabilities, dependency version mismatch, and deprecation issues.
In GitHub's top 400 repositories of all time
daisyUI CSS file is available on CDN
daisyUI uses semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
daisyUI provides tokens, root-level CSS variables and component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
daisyUI can be used as a standalone file, with Tailwind CSS standalone version. This is useful for projects without a Node.js environment.
daisyUI provides micro CSS files for each component
daisyUI uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
daisyUI uses native CSS nesting, reducing the CSS file size
Comparing daisyUI and Bootstrap: What are the main differences?

Thousands of developers have starred daisyUI on GitHub, indicating their trust and interest in the project. Bootstrap includes essential components. daisyUI's component count is higher than Bootstrap's. daisyUI keeps things simple for your project by having no dependencies
Bootstrap includes essential components. daisyUI's component count is higher than Bootstrap's.
Bootstrap's theming system works well for many use cases. If you need to change themes dynamically (e.g., for user preference), daisyUI's runtime CSS variable approach makes this easier.
Thousands of developers have starred daisyUI on GitHub, indicating their trust and interest in the project. Developers download daisyUI thousands of times every day, indicating constant usage
Thousands of developers have starred daisyUI on GitHub, indicating their trust and interest in the project.
Developers download daisyUI thousands of times every day, indicating constant usage.
daisyUI keeps things simple for your project by having no dependencies.
daisyUI's main goal is to add pre-designed components to Tailwind CSS using class names. This approach differs from Bootstrap, which is more complicated to use and customizes components.
